text: 1. Let the women go back to their place.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 2. Who is he whom 1 we meditate on as the Self? Which 2 is the Self?

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 3. That by which we see (form), that by which we hear (sound), that by which we perceive smells, that by which we utter speech, that by which we distinguish sweet and not sweet, (1) and what comes from the heart and the mind, namely, perception, command, understanding, knowledge, wisdom, seeing, holding, thinking, considering, readiness (or suffering), remembering, conceiving, willing, breathing, loving, desiring?

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 4. No, all these are various names only of knowledge (the true Self). (2)

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 5. And that Self, consisting of (knowledge), is Brahman (m.) 3 , it is Indra, it is Pra g âpati 4 . All these Devas, these five great elements, earth, air, ether, water, fire, these and those which are, as it were, small and mixed 5 , and seeds of this kind and that kind, born from eggs, born from the womb., born from heat, born from germs 6 , horses, cows, men, elephants, and whatsoever breathes, whether walking or flying, and what is immoveable--all that is led (produced) by knowledge (the Self).

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 6. It rests on knowledge (the Self). The world

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: is led (produced) by knowledge (the Self). Knowledge is its cause 1 .

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 7. Knowledge is Brahman. (3)

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 8. He (Vâmadeva), having by this conscious self stepped forth from this world, and having obtained all desires in that heavenly world, became immortal, yea, he became immortal. Thus it is, Om. (4)
